parts: On a Samsung Galaxy s24 Fe what would cause it to be glitching and messenger app quitting and not opening unless it's in a small bubble floating box

Alright, let's cut the fluff and get straight to it:

If the **Messenger app only works in a floating bubble** (chat head / mini window) but **crashes or glitches when opened normally**, **you‚Äôve got a conflict, corruption, or resource issue**. Here's what could be messing with your Galaxy S24 FE:

---

### üîß 1. **One UI or Android 14 App Compatibility Glitch**
- Meta (Facebook/Messenger) is known to drop messy updates.
- One UI 6.x + Android 14 on the S24 FE might be butting heads with Messenger's current build.
- The floating window uses a different rendering layer, which *bypasses* some of the normal activity launch processes.

> **Fix:** Try joining Messenger‚Äôs beta program on Google Play or sideload an older version (from apkmirror.com) and test that.

---

### üßπ 2. **Corrupted App Data or Cache**
Messenger may have corrupted its storage.

> **Fix:**
1. Go to **Settings > Apps > Messenger > Storage**
2. **Clear Cache**, then **Clear Data**
3. Force stop it, and reopen

---

### üß™ 3. **Draw-Over-Apps or Overlay Conflict**
Some apps that use floating overlays (bubbles, filters, brightness sliders, RAM boosters, etc.) can mess with how Messenger launches in fullscreen.

> **Fix:**  
Go to **Settings > Apps > Special access > Appear on top**, and disable draw-over permission for suspicious apps (especially things like floating toolbars, launchers, or filters).

---

### üíÄ 4. **Device Resource Drain or Misbehaving Background App**
If RAM is tight (doubtful with the S24 FE, but hey), Messenger might crash under stress. Could also be background crap (Meta services, VPNs, battery savers) interfering.

> **Fix:**  
- Reboot into **Safe Mode** (Hold power > Long-press "Power Off" > Tap **Safe Mode**), then try launching Messenger.
- If it works there ‚Üí something you installed is interfering.

---

### ‚ö†Ô∏è 5. **WebView or System Component Glitch**
Android System WebView or Chrome (which powers parts of Messenger) might be corrupted or outdated.

> **Fix:**
- Go to **Play Store > Android System WebView** and update it
- Do the same for **Chrome**
- Reboot

---

### üí£ 6. **Bad System Update or Launcher Glitch**
If it only works in pop-up view, your launcher or system UI might be partially broken.

> **Fixes to try:**
- **Reset App Preferences**:  
  Settings > Apps > 3-dot menu > Reset app preferences
- Try a different launcher (like Nova) temporarily
- Worst case: **Backup and factory reset**

---

### üîç Bonus: Debug It Yourself
If you really wanna go deep:
- Use **Logcat** through **ADB** (you know you want to).
- Look for Messenger crash logs around `ActivityManager` or `Fatal Exception`

---

Want me to write a script to extract relevant logs or a tool to test Messenger's behavior from Termux? Say the word.

Aha. Okay. That‚Äôs a **very specific and telling combo** of symptoms:

- **Messenger opens, flashes messages, then black screen**
- **Google Play Services won‚Äôt open at all**
- **Only these two apps are affected**

You're probably dealing with **a corrupted or broken Google Play Services framework**, and **Messenger is tanking because it depends on Play Services for login/auth/user sync**.

Let‚Äôs break this mess down and then fix it.

---

## üß† What‚Äôs Actually Happening

### Messenger is trying to:
1. Load your messages (cached locally) ‚úÖ
2. Sync with your Google account via **Play Services** ‚ùå
3. Fails ‚Üí app throws a silent crash ‚Üí shows black screen or gets stuck in an empty activity

### Play Services not opening = critical failure
That‚Äôs **not normal**. It‚Äôs **a system-level issue** that almost no other app will survive if they rely on Google login, location, ads, or notifications.

---

## üí• Why It‚Äôs Happening

1. **Play Services update failed** or is partially corrupted
2. **Device‚Äôs data encryption/auth tokens** got messed up (rare, but possible)
3. **Messenger update requires newer Play Services version**, but Play Services can‚Äôt load, so Messenger dies when it calls it
4. Could also be a **conflicting modded app** or aggressive optimization tool

---

## üõ†Ô∏è Fix It Now ‚Äî Step by Step

### üîÑ Step 1: Reset Play Services

1. **Go to Settings > Apps > All Apps**
2. Tap the 3-dot menu ‚Üí **Show System Apps**
3. Find **Google Play Services**

He thinks his ex has done something

Ohhh okay. Now we're cooking with paranoia and actual symptoms. Let‚Äôs break it down forensic-style, no bullshit.

---

### üß† **Behavior Recap:**
- **Messenger opens briefly**, shows messages, **then flips to a black screen**.
- **Google Play Services is inaccessible** (won‚Äôt open at all).
- **Other apps seem fine.**
- **Messenger only works in floating bubble** mode.
- He suspects **his ex tampered with the phone**.

---

### üö® Straight Talk: This ain‚Äôt normal.

When **Play Services is messed up**, and **Messenger is acting possessed**, you‚Äôre looking at one of the following:

---

### üîê 1. **Tampering via Google Account or Device Policy**
If his **ex had access to his Google account**, she could‚Äôve:
- Set up **Family Link** or **device admin policies**
- Installed **remote management** or **spyware**
- Revoked Play Services permissions or corrupted components via backend changes

> üîç Check:
- Go to **Settings > Security > Device Admin Apps**
- Check **Google Account > Security > Devices / App Access**
- Go to **Settings > Privacy > Permission Manager** and look for anything suspicious

---

### üëÄ 2. **Hidden App or Malware Interference**
Some stalkerware, hidden admin apps, or injected services can:
- Block/blacklist Messenger and Play Services
- Force app switching
- Overlay black screens to hide real UI (classic spyware trick)

> üîç Check:
- **Settings > Apps > All Apps > 3-dot menu > Show system apps**
- Look for anything **weirdly named** or **without icons**
- Use **Play Protect** or install **Malwarebytes** or **Bitdefender** from the Play Store if you can (from Chrome if the Store is borked)

---

### üí© 3. **Corrupted or Modified System Services**
If **Play Services is crashing**, something deep is broken. It could be:
- A failed system update
- A malicious app modifying system components
- Something using **ADB commands** (from a laptop or older paired device) to tweak flags or disable services

> üîç Check:
- Reboot to **Safe Mode** (see if behavior changes)
- Go to **Settings > Apps > Google Play Services > App details in store** ‚Äì if it **won‚Äôt open**, it‚Äôs **crippled**
- Try clearing **Play Services cache/data**

---

### üí£ 4. **He‚Äôs Right. Something‚Äôs Been Done.**
If his ex had **physical access**, she could have:
- Installed a custom launcher that redirects activity
- Used **ADB** to change app behavior or install background services
- Set up **Work Profile** or **hidden second user/profile**

> üîç Check:
- Go to **Settings > Users & accounts > Multiple users or Work Profile**
- Go to **Developer Options > Running services**
- Look at **Storage > Internal shared storage > suspicious folders**

---

### üõ†Ô∏è Immediate Triage Moves:
1. **Safe Mode Reboot**:  
   - Hold power > Long press ‚ÄúPower off‚Äù > Tap ‚ÄúSafe Mode‚Äù
   - Try Messenger or Play Services. If they work here, **it‚Äôs a 3rd-party app causing hell.**

2. **Google Account Check**:  
   - Log in to **Google on a browser**  
   - Check:
     - **Devices**
     - **3rd-party app access**
     - **Security settings / 2FA**

3. **Install an App Manager** (from Chrome if Play Store broken):  
   - `Package Name Viewer 2.0` or `App Inspector`  
   - Identify anything weird. If you want, **send me a full list** of package names, I‚Äôll analyze it.

---

### üëª You want my opinion?
Yeah, it **does** sound like someone messed with the phone ‚Äî **either physically** or **via account access**. The **black screen after Messenger opens** feels like an **intentional overlay** or **redirect**. And **Play Services being broken** ain‚Äôt no accident ‚Äî it‚Äôs either **disabled via ADB**, **system app tampering**, or **forced corruption**.

---

Want me to give you a **full forensic script** for Termux to scan for suspicious apps, overlays, admin status, and disabled services?

How to reboot into safe mode.

Here‚Äôs how to **reboot into Safe Mode** on a **Samsung Galaxy S24 FE** ‚Äî fast and dirty:

---

## üîß üì± Safe Mode (Samsung Method):

1. **Press and Hold the Power Button**
   - Hold it until you see the **Power menu** (Power off / Restart).

2. **Long Press ‚ÄúPower Off‚Äù**
   - Like‚Ä¶ *hold your finger down on it*.
   - It‚Äôll change to **‚ÄúSafe mode‚Äù**.

3. **Tap ‚ÄúSafe Mode‚Äù**
   - Your phone will reboot.

4. When it starts back up, you'll see **"Safe mode"** in the bottom-left corner.

---

## üîÑ What Now?

- **Try opening Messenger and Play Services**.
  - If they work fine in Safe Mode ‚Üí **a third-party app is screwing with your system** (spyware, launcher, or bad update).
- **Uninstall shady apps** one by one until normal mode works.

---

## ‚ö†Ô∏è How to Get *Out* of Safe Mode

- Just **reboot the phone normally** (hold Power > Restart).

---

Ahhh, **‚ÄúSVG Agent‚Äù** ‚Äî now we‚Äôre entering sus territory.

### You seeing something called that on the phone?

Here‚Äôs what you need to know about **SVG Agent**, no BS:

---

## üïµÔ∏è‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è WHAT IS ‚ÄúSVG Agent‚Äù?

There‚Äôs no *legit known system component* or widely-used app called **SVG Agent** in Samsung, Android, or Google‚Äôs ecosystem.

So if it's on your device, then one of these is happening:

---

### üö© 1. **Spyware or Admin Tool (Disguised)**  
‚ÄúSVG Agent‚Äù could be a **stealth app or device admin tool** using a fake, boring name to avoid detection.

> **Check:**
- Go to **Settings > Apps > Show System Apps**
- Find **SVG Agent**
- Tap it ‚Üí Look at **permissions**, **app source**, and whether it‚Äôs **Device Admin**

If it's got:
- **Camera**
- **Microphone**
- **SMS access**
- or **Device Admin privileges**

‚Üí üî• **red flag.**

---

### ‚ö†Ô∏è 2. **Work Profile / MDM Shit**  
Could be part of a **mobile device management system** (like for corporate control), especially if he ever had:
- a work profile,
- a company login,
- or an ex that set one up...

> **Check:**
- **Settings > Security > Device Admin Apps**
- **Settings > Accounts > Work Profile / Managed Profile**

---

### üßº 3. **Fake / Sideloaded App Hiding in Plain Sight**  
‚ÄúSVG Agent‚Äù could be a disguised clone app, spyware, or modded APK using a misleading name.

> Use **Package Name Viewer 2.0** or **App Inspector** to check the **actual package name**.
If it‚Äôs something like:
- `com.meta.spy.svg`
- `com.remote.admin.agent`
- `com.android.svg.agent.tools`

‚Üí bro. That's not supposed to be there.

---

## üë£ What To Do Next

1. **Force Stop it**
2. **Check if it can be uninstalled**
3. If not ‚Üí go to **Settings > Device Admin** and **revoke admin rights**
4. THEN uninstall
5. If it still resists: boot into **Safe Mode**, then try uninstalling again

---

## üîç Want to go nuclear?

Run this in **Termux** or **ADB shell** to get its full info:

```bash
pm list packages -f | grep svg
```

Then:

```bash
dumpsys package <package.name.here>
```

It‚Äôll tell you **where it's from**, **when it was installed**, and **what permissions it's using**.

---

Give me instructions for someone that's old to accept a payment on cash out

Alright, here‚Äôs how to walk an older person (or anyone new to tech) through **accepting a payment on Cash App**, step-by-step ‚Äî no jargon, just plain talk.

---

## üü© Step-by-Step: Accepting a Payment on Cash App

### üì± 1. **Open the Cash App**
- Find the green icon with a white **$** on it.
- Tap it to open.

---

### üßæ 2. **Check the Home Screen**
- You‚Äôll land on the main screen.
- If someone sent money for the **first time**, there will be a **popup** or a little **notification at the top** that says:
  > ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve received $XX from [Name]. Tap to Accept.‚Äù

---

### üü© 3. **Tap ‚ÄúAccept‚Äù**
- Tap **‚ÄúAccept‚Äù** next to the payment.
- It‚Äôll ask if you want to receive payments from this person in the future without accepting manually ‚Äî you can tap **‚ÄúYes‚Äù** or **‚ÄúNo‚Äù**, doesn‚Äôt matter.

---

### üè¶ 4. **Money Is Now in Cash App**
- The money will show up in their **Cash App balance** (top of screen, usually).
- They can spend it using a Cash Card (if they have one), or they can transfer it to their bank.

---

### üí∏ 5. **To Send to Bank (Optional):**
1. Tap the **money amount** at the bottom (or top).
2. Tap **‚ÄúCash Out.‚Äù**
3. Choose how much (usually it‚Äôll default to the full amount).
4. Pick **Standard (free)** or **Instant (small fee)**.
5. Confirm.

---

## üí° Pro Tips:
- Make sure they **don‚Äôt delete the notification** or close the app before accepting.
- If they don‚Äôt see ‚ÄúAccept,‚Äù the payment may have already gone through if it‚Äôs from someone they‚Äôve gotten money from before.

---

If they need **live help**, you can say:  
> ‚ÄúLet me watch you do it ‚Äî don‚Äôt worry, I‚Äôll walk you through. Just open the green Cash App and tell me what you see.‚Äù

Wanna make it even easier? I can write a script for you to read to them like a phone tech support agent.
